text: I think more measurement of code invalidations needs to happen, and how to cut down on that (which <@UC8821DPY> has been doing), but in the future, I think we might get the the point where it would make sense to automatically cache generated machine code in shared libraries.  There’s no reason the cache would make things run out of space, if it cleared out old versions that weren’t being used anymore.

text:
Hard drive space is cheap vs my time.
We are down near the 1cent per GB mark

elements.text:
Hard drive space is cheap vs my time.
We are down near the 1cent per GB mark

text: that said, anyone still using a hard drive on a desktop has worse problems

elements.text: that said, anyone still using a hard drive on a desktop has worse problems

text:
Yeah, but I doubt they are slower than the compiler.
Given that compiling plots takes 10seconds. 
That is enough time to read over 500MB even on a old hard drive.
Though might not be much faster

elements.text:
Yeah, but I doubt they are slower than the compiler.

That is enough time to read over 500MB even on a old hard drive.
Though might not be much faster

text:
In any case even SSDs are down to 25c per GB.
Unlike hard drives it's not quite in the "emptying my recycle bin is a dubious economic decision" territory,
but it is still in the "I never run Pkg.gc, because what if need to install an old version of a package and I am on a plane?"

text: You could cache a subset of methods. Maybe have something similar to precompile statements.
